body:
You don’t have to attend a MIAM if any of the following apply:

- your application is urgent because there’s a risk to your or your children’s safety
- you or the other person has made an allegation of domestic abuse
- you’re already involved with social services due to concerns about your children’s safety or wellbeing
- your situation is about money and you or the other person is bankrupt
- you don’t want the other person to know you’re applying to court, and you have a good reason why they shouldn’t know (for example there’s safety concerns) 
- you or the other person is in prison or subject to bail conditions that prevent contact with each other
- you don’t know where the other person is
- you or the other person don’t normally live in either England or Wales
- you live further than 15 miles from a mediator
- you’ve contacted 3 mediators and can’t get an appointment within 15 working days 
- you or the other person has a disability and the mediator doesn’t have disabled facilities
- a mediator has stated mediation isn’t suitable or hasn’t worked - for example the other person isn’t willing to attend or you’ve tried - mediation and it’s been unsuccessful
- your application relates to another family issue that a court is dealing with
- you and the other person agree about arrangements and are applying for a consent order
heading:
Valid reasons not to attend a MIAM
